;;为什么像唐纳德·特朗普和乔·拜登这样出生于 20 世纪 40 年代的美国人对美国权力有如此大的束缚，为什么他们如此紧紧地抓住它呢？为了回答这个问题，我们的;US;编辑采访了数十位出生在同一十年的杰出美国人。结果是一个新的;六部分播客系列;将于本周开始。它被称为“繁荣！炸毁美国政治的一代人”。

;

;他们大约与原子弹同时出生，在一个前苏联时代的国家长大。 - 在技术、军事和经济方面杰出。他们的童年时期潜伏着对相互毁灭的恐惧，但这种恐惧大部分被舒适的家庭生活所消除。人们在十几岁到二十多岁之间形成自己的政治观点。对于这个群体来说，那是 20 世纪 60 年代末，这十年的可能性因战争、暗杀和街头暴力而中断。第一集聚焦于 1968 年，美国极端党派之争的起源故事。

;;;;当巴拉克·奥巴马 (Barack Obama); 于 2009 年就任总统时，这似乎不仅仅改变了后卫，却是一个时代的结束。过去 16 年里，出生于 20 世纪 40 年代的男性一直占据白宫；现在轮到新一代了。奥巴马先生出生于 20 世纪 60 年代。他的口号是“希望”和“改变”。他在众多回忆录中的一本中抱怨美国政治“发展停滞”，陷入“婴儿潮一代的心理剧”。他写道，是时候摆脱 20 世纪 60 年代大学校园里的陈旧争斗了。

;

;然而，奥巴马先生的任期发生了转变。这并不是与过去决裂，而只是暂时摆脱过去。随后的两位总统唐纳德·特朗普和乔·拜登也出生于 20 世纪 40 年代。由于他们是今年选举的两位主要候选人（至少目前如此），其中一位很可能再担任四年总统。即使拜登退出竞选，特朗普目前仍是最受欢迎的人。这意味着他们这一代人最终可能会在 1993 年至 2029 年的大部分时间里锁定总统职位——长达 40 年。

;;H;;历史、科学;和常识一致：即使是伟大的领导者也会变老。 1953年，温斯顿·丘吉尔在第二次担任首相期间，晚饭后中风。历史学家安德鲁·罗伯茨（Andrew Roberts）写道：“似乎没有人对他含糊不清的言语和脚步不稳感到惊慌，而这正是以酗酒闻名的优势之一。”几周来，由于丘吉尔无法执政，他的女婿和私人秘书实际上管理着这个国家。他从未完全康复，但直到 1955 年 80 岁时才拒绝下台。未来的保守党首相哈罗德·麦克米伦 (Harold Macmillan) 在 1954 年写道。

;

;对于大多数人来说，认知能力下降是这是一场私人悲剧，给亲人留下了伤痕，但很少有人受伤。当它困扰政治领导人时，损害可能是灾难性的。 1933 年德国总统保罗·冯·兴登堡 (Paul von Hindenburg) 并不喜欢阿道夫·希特勒 (Adolf Hitler)，但为了打破政治僵局，让他担任总理。一些历史学家将这一史诗般的误判归咎于他已经 85 岁了，疲惫不堪，而且可能还患有阿尔茨海默病。

;;一些;;一些火灾;很难扑灭。这场辩论是在乔·拜登总统;6月27日的灾难性辩论表现;，他结结巴巴、半清晰的辩论，正在发展成为一场大火。几天来，只有媒体——尽管包括与总统关系最密切的专栏作家和评论员——呼吁他放弃他的;竞选连任;。但从 7 月 2 日起，总统在民主党内的支持率开始出现下滑。来自德克萨斯州的代表劳埃德·道格特(Lloyd Doggett)成为第一位呼吁他下台的现任民主党议员。第二天，另一个人劳尔·格里哈尔瓦也加入了他的行列。大捐助者里德·黑斯廷斯也表示，拜登应该为另一位候选人让路。博彩市场在辩论当天上午将总统退出竞选的可能性定为 20%，而在 7 月 3 日则将这一可能性提高至 60% 以上。

;

;其他大人物一直在暗示;类似观点;，或者至少拒绝原谅拜登老糊涂的口齿不清。罗德岛州参议员谢尔登·怀特豪斯 (Sheldon Whitehouse) 告诉当地一家电视台，“和很多人一样，我对这场辩论感到非常震惊。”南卡罗来纳州代表、拜登的亲密盟友吉姆·克莱伯恩表示，他仍然支持总统，但如果他退出竞选，他将支持副总统卡马拉·哈里斯接替他。也许最重要的是，前众议院议长南希·佩洛西 (Nancy Pelosi) 最初对拜登的健康状况表示不屑，但现在她对采访者说：“我认为这是一个合理的问题，”这是一个插曲，还是一个条件？'”

; ; m ; m ; ; ost ost octogenarians ; opt为了轻松的生活。乔·拜登（Joe Biden）总统正在进行一项艰苦的，十亿美元的运动，以赢得继续工作的特权，直到他86岁。到底是什么目的？贝登在2019年的上一次竞选中说，他想拯救“国家的灵魂”，这意味着他剥夺了唐纳德·特朗普的总统职位。特朗普今年的复仇候选人资格促使拜登先生恢复了他的旧球场。我们的选举模式表明，总统在6月27日候选人之间的辩论可能会导致民意调查发生变化，但总统只有大约30％的机会获得连任。拜登先生的第二次胜利将适当地消除他的克星。但这也将使总统在白宫又有四年。他将如何处理它们？

; ; i ; i ; ;皇家海军与一对美国科技巨头Microsoft和Amazon Web Services接触了一个问题：有没有更好的方法来发动战争？更具体地说，他们能否找到一种更有效的方法来在加勒比海的一个假设突击队罢工团队与护卫舰的导弹系统之间进行协调？科技公司与; bae ;系统合作，巨型武器制造商，以及较小的新贵的安杜里尔（Anduril），以及其他军事承包商。在12周之内（在国防采购世界中，毫无意义的速度都很快）在英国的萨默塞特郡聚集了，以演示被称为Stormcloud的东西。

;

;海军陆战队在地面上，空气中的无人机和许多其他传感器连接到高级收音机的“网眼”网络，使每个传感器都可以无缝地看到其他地方发生的事情 - 这种设置已经允许海军陆战队运行在先前的练习中围绕更大的力量圈出。他们收集的数据均在网络的“边缘”上处理，这些数据在带有蹦极电缆的突击队的小型，坚固的计算机上，以及在遥远的云服务器上，在卫星发送的远处云服务器上。命令与控制软件监视了指定区域，决定哪个无人机应飞行，在地面上识别对象，并建议撞击哪种武器。

;So it is troubling that Mr Ramaphosa may soon have to make a momentous choice. ;;P;;RESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES; is a coveted job, at least among a certain type of power-crazed geriatric man. America's founders nearly made the office more exalted still. John Adams, the first vice-president, thought the president should be known as His Elective Majesty or His Mightiness. The Senate endorsed another form of address: His Highness, the President of the United States and Protector of their Liberties. But the House of Representatives rejected grand titles, and George Washington went along with it to dispel claims that he had monarchical ambitions. The accusations flew anyway, and have been repeated whenever one party dislikes what the president is up to, which is to say most of the time.

;

;Novelists have ;taken such fears further;, imagining the overthrow of American democracy by a charismatic dictator: President Buzz Windrip in Sinclair Lewis's “It Can't Happen Here” (1935), Nehemiah Scudder in Robert Heinlein's sci-fi series “If This Goes On” (1941), Charles Lindbergh in Philip Roth's “The Plot Against America” (2004). President Scudder, a preacher-turned-politician from the boondocks, wins the election of 2012. The election of 2016 is then cancelled.

;

;As November's election draws near, it is not just novelists who are imagining similar scenarios. Democrats see Donald Trump as a would-be tyrant because of his attempt to remain in office after losing the election of 2020. Mr Trump, for his part, denounces Joe Biden, who won the election despite Mr Trump's scheming, as a usurper. Mr Trump claims Mr Biden is abusing his authority to initiate bogus legal proceedings and so get Mr Trump locked up. Mr Biden, together “with a band of his closest thugs, misfits and Marxists”, is trying “to destroy American democracy”.

;;I;;N LATE APRIL;, for the 75th time in a row, America blocked a mundane motion at the World Trade Organisation to fill vacancies on the panel that is the final arbiter of disputes among the group's members. The relentless vetoes, obscure as they might sound, have in effect completely defanged the ;WTO; for almost five years. Members that are found to have violated its rules can simply appeal against the decision, to a panel that is not functioning for lack of personnel. While the appeals moulder, the transgressions go unpunished. Two years ago, at one of the ;WTO;'s biennial summits, members resolved to get the dispute-resolution mechanism up and running again by this year. At the latest summit, earlier this year, having failed to do so, they instead decided, without even a hint of irony, to “accelerate discussions”.

;

;The dysfunction at the ;WTO; is emblematic of a world where the institutions and rules intended to foster international trade and investment are falling into abeyance. Every day brings alarming new headlines. The European Union, although supposedly both more supportive of free trade and more determined to reduce its greenhouse-gas emissions than other economic powers, is on the verge of imposing duties on Chinese electric vehicles. Last month ;EU; officials raided a big Chinese security-equipment maker as part of a probe into subsidies. America recently imposed sanctions on more than 300 entities, including some in China and Turkey, for providing support to Russia's armed forces.

Russia's progress is a reflection of its overwhelming advantage in firepower: on some parts of the front line, for every shell the Ukrainians have shot at Russian lines, the Russians have rained down 17 in response. ;;T;;HE residentS; of northern Italy had never seen anything like the thunderstorm that mauled their region last夏天。 Hailstones as big as 19cm across pummelled Milan, Parma, Turin and Venice. Windows were broken, solar panels smashed, tiles cracked and cars dented. The episode cost the insurance industry $4.8bn, making it the most expensive natural disaster in the world from July to September (the figures exclude America, which collates such data separately).

;Yet insurance executives, although smarting, were not surprised. Climate change is making such incidents much more common. In the decade from 2000 to 2009 only three thunderstorms cost the industry more than $1bn at current prices. From 2010 to 2019 there were ten. Since 2020 there have already been six. Such storms now account for more than a quarter of the costs to the insurance industry from natural disasters, according to Swiss Re, a reinsurance firm. In Europe, not known for extreme weather, losses have topped $5bn a year for the past three years.

;;I;;S DETERRENCE easy; or hard? That simple question has been at the heart of nuclear strategy for almost 80 years. For Bernard Brodie, an early nuclear theorist, the bomb had created a stable balance of terror. The precise number and variety of weapons was less important than the fact that they existed. His colleagues Herman Kahn and Albert Wohlstetter disagreed. ;;J;;OHN BOLTON;, Donald Trump's national security adviser in 2018-19, has simple advice for anyone trying to understand his former boss's philosophy on foreign policy: don't bother. Mr Bolton, who fell out with Mr Trump, says the former president has no consistent principles, only moods, grudges and an obsession with his image. Thus he could both threaten North Korea with “fire and fury” and hold three chummy summits with Kim Jong Un, for example, or both talk about leaving the ;NATO; alliance and then reinforce its eastern flank.

;Mr Trump's current acolytes retort that “America First” is a perfectly coherent ideology, which was never properly adopted owing to obstructive advisers like Mr Bolton and the inexperience of the ex-president's true devotees. ;;“I; ;WISH I; could say we have a very detailed plan,” an Israeli army officer admitted to your correspondent in the chaotic days following Hamas's brutal assault on southern Israel on October 7th. More than 1,100 people had been killed; some 240 had been dragged back to Gaza as hostages. It was clear from the outset of the war in Gaza, now six months old, that Israel's two main goals—to eliminate Hamas and to free the hostages—were at odds. It was also clear that invading the territory, in which 2.2m people live cheek by jowl and under which Hamas had built a labyrinth of fortified tunnels to help it withstand an attack, was going to be immensely difficult. And there was always the risk that war in Gaza would spiral into a bigger conflict.

;

;It is possible to look at this unpromising starting point and conclude that Israel's invasion of Gaza has not gone badly—and many Israelis take just that view. After all, Hamas's fighting capacity has been massively reduced, with little in the way of Israeli casualties. Some of the hostages have been released and negotiations continue in an attempt to free the remainder. And all the while, there has been no regional conflagration, nor even much unrest in the West Bank (the more populous of the two Palestinian territories) or among Israelis of Palestinian origin.
